channel.title: Pod Pod Pod — A Podcast Playlist
channel.itunes:author: Jeff Ruberg
channel.itunes:summary: A curated playlist of just the best podcasts—because sometimes the world of podcasts is loud and overwhelming. New episodes every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.
channel.description: A curated playlist of just the best podcasts—because sometimes the world of podcasts is loud and overwhelming. New episodes every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

item.title: 99% Invisible #195: Best Enjoyed By
item.itunes:subtitle: Expiration Labels
item.itunes:author: 99% Invisible
item.description: Where do food expiration labels come from, and what do they really mean? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: Where do food expiration labels come from, and what do they really mean? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
Where do food expiration labels come from, and what do they really mean?

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on 99percentinvisible.org
  • Check out more 99% Invisible
  • Subscribe to 99% Invisible
  • Episode originally published on January 11, 2015
Date labels (e.g. "use-by", "sell-by", "best-by", "best if used by," "expires on", etc.) are on a lot of products. Forty-one states require a date label on at least some food product, but there are huge inconsistencies, not just in the wording, but in the meaning of these labels. Some states require them only on dairy, some on shellfish, some on any perishable foods. It's become complicated to decipher these dates, or to know how to act on them, for large retailers and individual consumers alike. And despite what many people assume, they are not about food safety, and were actually never meant to be.

item.title: Planet Money #666: The Hoverboard Life
item.itunes:subtitle: Hoverboard Origin
item.itunes:author: Planet Money
item.description: Where did hoverboards come from? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: Where did hoverboards come from? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

Where did hoverboards come from?

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on npr.org
  • Check out more Planet Money
  • Subscribe to Planet Money
  • Episode originally published on November 27, 2015
The hottest toy this holiday season has no identifiable logo, no main distributor, and no widely agreed upon name. Today, we seek out the origin of the hands-free, two wheeled, self-balancing scooter.

item.title: StartUp Podcast #19: Diversity Report
item.itunes:subtitle: Gimlet Diversity
item.itunes:author: StartUp Podcast
item.description: An interesting look at the challenges, importance, and meaning of diversity for a company. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: An interesting look at the challenges, importance, and meaning of diversity for a company. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
An interesting look at the challenges, importance, and meaning of diversity for a company.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on gimletmedia.com
  • Check out more StartUp Podcast
  • Subscribe to StartUp Podcast
  • Episode originally published on December 18, 2015
If you were to walk into Gimlet HQ, there are a few things you’d probably notice right off the bat. First, it’s crowded - like a grungy dorm room. Second, the lighting… it’s not great. Not many windows. Third, it’s white. Really white. 24 of Gimlet’s 27 employees are white. In this episode, we look at diversity (or lack thereof) at Gimlet. And we try to figure out what diversity should mean for the company going forward.

item.title: The Bright Sessions #1: Check Out: The Bright Sessions
item.itunes:subtitle: The Bright Sessions
item.itunes:author: The Bright Sessions
item.description:
Fiction podcasts have been on the rise lately, but I've found it very difficult to connect to most of them. But The Bright Sessions has hooked me in, with a great mix of intriguing science fiction premise, novel (but very natural) format, and serialization.
Each episode is a therapy session with a supernatural individual learning to deal with their super power (and the first season is following the ongoing sessions of 3 characters). It's a set of character studies, but it's also an interesting exploration of the consequences of flashy world-threatening powers on the emotions and turmoils of daily life.
I'm featuring the first episode because it's definitely worth starting from the beginning, and I hope you get hooked. I've really enjoyed the first 6 episodes, and I'm excited to see where this podcast goes. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on thebrightsessions.com
  • Check out more The Bright Sessions
  • Subscribe to The Bright Sessions
  • Episode originally published on October 27, 2015
Session 1 with Samantha Barnes, a young woman with a Level 10, Class D ability. She found me through the ad I placed in the paper offering "therapy for the strange and unusual".

item.title: Reply All #46: Yik Yak Returns
item.itunes:subtitle: Yik Yak Returns
item.itunes:author: Reply All
item.description: What racism looks like in our modern age. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: What racism looks like in our modern age. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
What racism looks like in our modern age.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on gimletmedia.com
  • Check out more Reply All
  • Subscribe to Reply All
  • Episode originally published on November 18, 2015
Yik Yak is an app that allows users to communicate anonymously with anyone within a 10-mile radius. Last year, we did a story about how it brought out a particularly vicious strain of racism at Colgate University. And in the second half of the show - The past month has seen a flood of similar stories at colleges like University of Missouri, Yale, and Georgetown. So we go beyond Colgate and talk to Jamil Smith of the Intersection podcast to try to understand Colgate in the context of these recent events.

item.title: 99% Invisible #188: Fountain Drinks
item.itunes:subtitle: Water Fountains
item.itunes:author: 99% Invisible
item.description: Another episode of 99% Invisible about the surprising and fascinating history of something we find extremely common: drinking water. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: Another episode of 99% Invisible about the surprising and fascinating history of something we find extremely common: drinking water. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
Another episode of 99% Invisible about the surprising and fascinating history of something we find extremely common: drinking water.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on 99percentinvisible.org
  • Check out more 99% Invisible
  • Subscribe to 99% Invisible
  • Episode originally published on November 10, 2015
On April 21st, 1859, an incredible thing happened in London and thousands of people came out to celebrate it. Women wore their finest clothing. Men were in suits and top hats, and children clamored to get a glimpse... of the very first public drinking fountain.

item.title: StartUp Podcast #16: The Secret Formula
item.itunes:subtitle: Gimlet Show Development
item.itunes:author: StartUp Podcast
item.description: A look at how Gimlet develops a new podcast idea. I always find it fascinating to learn more about the behind-the-scenes production of NPR-style podcasts. I think as listeners we have a vague sense that "yeah, it's scripted", but not really a sense as to how deep that goes; what we see is the tip of the iceberg of the work that goes into these shows. And this episode is particularly interesting because it looks at the creation and development of a new podcast, which is even more unknown and invisible to listeners. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: A look at how Gimlet develops a new podcast idea. I always find it fascinating to learn more about the behind-the-scenes production of NPR-style podcasts. And this episode is particularly interesting because it looks at the creation and development of a new podcast, which is even more unknown and invisible to listeners. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
A look at how Gimlet develops a new podcast idea. I always find it fascinating to learn more about the behind-the-scenes production of NPR-style podcasts. I think as listeners we have a vague sense that "yeah, it's scripted", but not really a sense as to how deep that goes; what we see is the tip of the iceberg of the work that goes into these shows. And this episode is particularly interesting because it looks at the creation and development of a new podcast, which is even more unknown and invisible to listeners.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on gimletmedia.com
  • Check out more StartUp Podcast
  • Subscribe to StartUp Podcast
  • Episode originally published on November 06, 2015
Gimlet is making a big, expensive bet. The kind of bet that could make or break the company. And it’s a bet that comes down to one factor: What is Gimlet’s competitive advantage? As the company launches its fourth new show, “Surprisingly Awesome,” we take a deep dive in to how the show was made. From the kernel of an idea to the final product. And, along the way, we look at what we believe is Gimlet’s secret formula for making podcasts.

item.title: On the Media: Inside/Outside
item.itunes:subtitle: The Outsider Narrative
item.itunes:author: On the Media
item.description: An interesting look at the history of the "outsider" narrative of presidential candidates. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: An interesting look at the history of the "outsider" narrative of presidential candidates. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
An interesting look at the history of the "outsider" narrative of presidential candidates.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on onthemedia.org
  • Check out more On the Media
  • Subscribe to On the Media
  • Episode originally published on October 30, 2015
The launch of a collaboration between On the Media and Nate Silver’s 538 to track the push and pull between polling, media coverage, and public interest in candidates. Plus: a look at the long history of savvy political candidates campaigning as Washington "outsiders"; debunking the supposed "Ferguson effect"; and Spotlight, a new movie about the Boston Globe's investigation into the Catholic Church sex scandal, celebrates the power of the press.

(This is a rebroadcast of an episode that originally aired in July 2014, but is just as relevant today as it was then.) What would it be like if everyone at your office knew what everyone else earned? On today's show, we hear about a company where salaries aren't secret.

item.title: 99% Invisible #186: War and Pizza
item.itunes:subtitle: Food Preservation
item.itunes:author: 99% Invisible
item.description: How do we get food that can sit in our pantry for years? Where do the chemicals that occupy grocery isles come from? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: How do we get food that can sit in our pantry for years? Where do the chemicals that occupy grocery isles come from? If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
How do we get food that can sit in our pantry for years? Where do the chemicals that occupy grocery isles come from?

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on 99percentinvisible.org
  • Check out more 99% Invisible
  • Subscribe to 99% Invisible
  • Episode originally published on October 28, 2015
Households tend to take pantry food for granted, but canned beans, powered cheese, and bags of moist cookies were not designed for everyday convenience. These standard products were made to meet the needs of the military. Reporter Tina Antolini, host of the podcast Gravy, tells the story.

item.title: Note to Self: How to Shake Up Your Echo Chamber
item.itunes:subtitle: Shake Up Echo Chamber
item.itunes:author: Note to Self
item.description: Great chat with hosts of three of the best podcasts about expanding outside your social media echo chamber and broadening your perspective. I often hear that people are fed up with the same discussions over and over again on social media, and I've always felt that's just their own fault for whom they choose to follow (the same goes for podcasts). If you've felt like you need a change of pace, this is a great place to start. Also check out the accompanying [blog post](http://www.wnyc.org/story/buzzfeed-professional-internet-readers-break-bubble/) for extra notes and tips that weren't mentioned on the show. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

I often hear that people are fed up with the same discussions over and over again on social media, and I've always felt that's just their own fault for whom they choose to follow (the same goes for podcasts). If you've felt like you need a change of pace, this is a great place to start. Also check out the accompanying [blog post](http://www.wnyc.org/story/buzzfeed-professional-internet-readers-break-bubble/) for extra notes and tips that weren't mentioned on the show. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
Great chat with hosts of three of the best podcasts about expanding outside your social media echo chamber and broadening your perspective. I often hear that people are fed up with the same discussions over and over again on social media, and I've always felt that's just their own fault for whom they choose to follow (the same goes for podcasts). If you've felt like you need a change of pace, this is a great place to start. Also check out the accompanying blog post for extra notes and tips that weren't mentioned on the show.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on wnyc.org
  • Check out more Note to Self
  • Subscribe to Note to Self
  • Episode originally published on October 21, 2015
Some people call it the “echo chamber effect.” Others worry about filter bubbles or homophily. Every once in awhile you'll hear hands wringing over birds of a feather. Or you could just say it like listener Anid Chan in Portland: “I have a concern about personalized feeds. There is so much information out there, but I know that most of what I see are opinions and voices like my own. I worry this makes us more judgmental about other people, because most of what we believe gets emphasized by people who think the same way. How do we break out of the bubble?”

item.title: Reasonably Sound #30: Bits and Chips
item.itunes:subtitle: Chiptunes
item.itunes:author: Reasonably Sound
item.description: A really cool look into the world of chiptunes—a great listen if you have any interest in classic video game music. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: A really cool look into the world of chiptunes—a great listen if you have any interest in classic video game music. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
A really cool look into the world of chiptunes—a great listen if you have any interest in classic video game music.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on infiniteguest.org
  • Check out more Reasonably Sound
  • Subscribe to Reasonably Sound
  • Episode originally published on October 15, 2015
It's all about nostalgia and limitation as Mike chips away (ahhh?!?!?) at the world of chiptunes music. If you played video games years and years ago, you'll hear a set of sounds that will be completely familiar, even when used in unfamiliar compositional genres. Mike explores the anatomy of chiptunes sounds and composition, and looks into chiptunes' relationship to hacking and the counterculture.

item.title: Criminal #28: P.D.I.D.
item.itunes:subtitle: Transgender Processing
item.itunes:author: Criminal
item.description: An important look at how police treated a transgender woman in 2009. Even with all the progress we've made in transgender rights in the intervening six years, transphobia is still rampant, and this is a brutal look into how it manifests. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: An important look at how police treated a transgender woman in 2009. Even with all the progress we've made in transgender rights in the intervening six years, transphobia is still rampant, and this is a brutal look into how it manifests. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.content:encoded:
An important look at how police treated a transgender woman in 2009. Even with all the progress we've made in transgender rights in the intervening six years, transphobia is still rampant, and this is a brutal look into how it manifests.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on thisiscriminal.com
  • Check out more Criminal
  • Subscribe to Criminal
  • Episode originally published on October 09, 2015
Patti Hammond Shaw is a transgender woman. She's legally female on her birth certificate and driver's license, and has been since 1993. But when she was arrested in 2009, male officers strip-searched her in front of male detainees, and held her overnight in a men's cellblock. Patti hired a lawyer and fought back. Her case was instrumental in changing how the police process and detain transgender individuals in Washington, DC.

item.title: Between the Liner Notes #3: I Want My MTV
item.itunes:subtitle: MTV Origin
item.itunes:author: Between the Liner Notes
item.description: I have little interest in music, but I grew up in an era where the existence of MTV was a given part of life. Which makes hearing about the large obstacles faced in MTV's creation extremely fascinating. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out more Between the Liner Notes
  • Subscribe to Between the Liner Notes
  • Episode originally published on October 04, 2015
In 1981, no one believed people would watch a cable channel that aired music videos 24 hours a day. This is the story about how MTV proved them all wrong.

item.title: On the Media: After Oregon
item.itunes:subtitle: After Oregon
item.itunes:author: On the Media
item.description: An important look at the role the media plays in mass shootings. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: An important look at the role the media plays in mass shootings. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on onthemedia.org
  • Check out more On the Media
  • Subscribe to On the Media
  • Episode originally published on October 03, 2015
Searching for answers after a tragedy like the shooting at Umpqua Community College can be difficult. But some laws have made searching for even the most basic answers - such as how many concealed weapons owners live in a state - just as difficult to find.

item.title: Note to Self: Why Google ‘Thought’ This Black Woman Was a Gorilla
item.itunes:subtitle: Racist AI
item.itunes:author: Note to Self
item.description: This episode is a great and important reminder that not only is the current state of AI much dumber than we think, but also much more biased by the demographics of its creators than we'd like to believe. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Subscribe to Note to Self
  • Episode originally published on September 30, 2015
This is a story about an incident that happened to 22-year-old freelance web developer Jacky Alciné, the racist slur that caught him off-guard, and the machines behind it.

item.title: Radiolab: Darkode
item.itunes:subtitle: Digital Ransom
item.itunes:author: Radiolab
item.description: I swear one day I won't feature Radiolab every week, but today is not that day. This episode has two halves: the first is a thrilling and fascinating story about being hacked, and the second is a look behind the network that enables those activities. It's really great, and totally worth my guilt of featuring the same show three weeks in a row. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

Rainy wanted to understand why she stayed with an older boyfriend who humiliated and physically abused her. So she spent two years reporting from inside the relationship.

item.title: Out on the Wire #1: Eureka
item.itunes:subtitle: Making Stories
item.itunes:author: Out on the Wire
item.description: If you're interested in making narrative nonfiction radio someday, this new podcast is a must-listen. But I'm not interested in getting into radio someday; I enjoy this podcast for entirely different reasons, for the peeks behind the scenes of great shows and glimpses into what it takes to create compelling stories. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

Episode one is about ideas. We investigate how to find them and how to follow your taste with the help of Ira Glass, Alex Blumberg, Stephanie Foo, and more.

item.title: Untitled Patrick Rothfuss Podcast: Gandalf Already Knows Prismatic Spray
item.itunes:subtitle: Magic Mechanics
item.itunes:author: Untitled Patrick Rothfuss Podcast
item.description: I haven't read *The Name of the Wind* (though I've heard it's excellent). I'm not a big fan of Cards Against Humanity. But this podcast from Patrick Rothfuss, author of *The Name of the Wind*, and Max Temkin, of Cards Against Humanity, is really great. Their conversations are always interesting, but this episode really struck me with their discussion of the presence—or lack of—logical and well-presented rules behind fantasy magic. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

This week Max and Pat talk about childhood.

item.title: Radiolab: The Rhino Hunter
item.itunes:subtitle: Rhino Hunting
item.itunes:author: Radiolab
item.description: Part of me feels guilty because this marks my first repeat show recommendation, and in consequent episodes of the podcast nonetheless. But this epiosde was too great to pass up. It takes what may seem like a binary black-and-white issue and explores the nuance, the varied perspectives, to teach us not only about the intricacies of black rhino hunting in Namibia, but how complex so many issues can be. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Subscribe to Radiolab
  • Episode originally published on September 7, 2015
When shooting and killing an endangered species might be the best way to save it. This episode contains strong language.

item.title: The Cracked Podcast #85: Ben Franklin’s Secret Hack to Make People Like You
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben Franklin's Little Theory
item.itunes:author: The Cracked Podcast
item.description: The ear-catching (and definitely a bit clickbaity) theory described by this episode's title is interesting on a micro-level, but not exactly practical. Don't listen to learn a secret hack you can use to make people like you. Listen to this episode to hear the Cracked editors explore the ramifications of this theory in a fascinating and thought-provoking discusion about society. In particular, the way this theory intersects with and influences inequality is such an adept explanation for how vast inequalities arise, and how society's natural inclination is to trend towards inequality, rather than against it. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on http://www.earwolf.com/
  • Check out more The Cracked Podcast
  • Subscribe to The Cracked Podcast
  • Episode originally published on August 31, 2015
Growing up we were taught to abide by the golden rule: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. But that's hard to maintain. People get in the way and always seem to let you down, right? A co worker is a jerk to you and you don't know why....

item.title: Mother: A Podcast #7: What We Talk About When We Talk About Pregnancy Loss
item.itunes:subtitle: Pregnancy Loss
item.itunes:author: Mother: A Podcast
item.description: One of my favorite aspects of the podcast medium is the ability to hear stories from new perspectives, to grow my understanding of the world. As a guy, *Mother: A Podcast* fits that for me perfectly, though I'm sure the podcast would be even more interesting to mothers or women planning to become mothers one day. This latest episode of the podcast is a great collection of stories about pregnancy loss, which I found such a valuable experience because it is something I hear and think about very rarely and I can only begin to understand at a very abstract level. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary: One of my favorite aspects of the podcast medium is the ability to hear stories from new perspectives, to grow my understanding of the world.   • Check out this episode on motherapodcast.com
  • Check out more Mother: A Podcast
  • Subscribe to Mother: A Podcast
  • Episode originally published on August 20, 2015
Why is it so hard to talk about pregnancy loss? Contributor Miranda Shafer ([http://mirandashafer.com/](http://mirandashafer.com/)) asks some hard questions about how she reacted to her own sister's miscarriage. Amy explores the medical science underlying a case in Indiana where a woman who says she had a stillbirth was convicted of feticide. (Read more about the case here: [http://www.pri.org/stories/2015-03-13/indiana-jury-says-purvi-patel-should-go-prison-what-she-says-was-miscarriage](http://www.pri.org/stories/2015-03-13/indiana-jury-says-purvi-patel-should-go-prison-what-she-says-was-miscarriage)) And a Tumblr project ([http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/](http://pregnantparentingprochoice.tumblr.com/)) collects stories of mothers + soon-to-be moms who support abortion access.

item.title: Radiolab: Remembering Oliver Sacks
item.itunes:subtitle: Oliver Sacks
item.itunes:author: Radiolab
item.description: When the unfortunate news of Oliver Sacks's passing hit last week, I didn't know how to react. I had no idea who he was, just that people in public radio really loved him. Apparently Dr. Oliver Sacks provided many stories to *Radiolab* over the years. To honor his memory, *Radiolab* re-aired this episode from July, which is a great conversation with him and really shows why he was so loved. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on radiolab.org
  • Check out more Radiolab
  • Subscribe to Radiolab
  • Episode originally published on August 30, 2015
When Dr. Sacks announced a few months ago that he had terminal cancer and wouldn't do any more interviews, we asked him if he'd talk with us one last time. This is that conversation.

item.title: Death, Sex & Money: In New Orleans: From Raising Hell to Raising Kids
item.itunes:subtitle: In New Orleans
item.itunes:author: Death, Sex & Money
item.description: This is the first part in an excellent series of interviews *Death, Sex & Money* released last week to line up with the decade anniversary of Hurricane Katrina. Each interview offers a unique perspective on life in New Orleans. It's a great series, and you should definitely check out the [rest of the episodes](http://www.wnyc.org/story/in-new-orleans/) if you found this firts part compelling. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

Each interview offers a unique perspective on life in New Orleans. It's a great series, and you should definitely check out the rest of the episodes if you found this firts part compelling.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on www.wnyc.org
  • Check out more Death, Sex & Money
  • Subscribe to Death, Sex & Money
  • Episode originally published on August 17, 2015
A decade after Hurricane Katrina, Terri Coleman is teaching a summer class to incoming students at Dillard University—a historically black college in New Orleans. But 10 years ago, when she was about the same age as her students, she was not the kind of kid to get a jump on freshman year with a summer class… Now married with three children and a graduate degree, Terri recently returned to her old neighborhood after spending a few years in Illinois. She tells me about her mixed emotions regarding what’s been lost in the post-Katrina rebuilding of New Orleans. “Clearly I'm here for white hipster game,” she laughs. “But as a class of people, I think they're really dangerous to the city.”

item.title: You're the Expert: Inside a Dog's Brain
item.itunes:subtitle: Dog Psychology
item.itunes:author: You're the Expert
item.description:
I'm not a dog person. I might go so far as to say that I hate dogs (except huskies, because wolves). And yet I found this episode all about a puppy psychologist fascinating, engaging, and hillarious.
This was also the first episode of *You're the Expert* I'd heard, and I'm very impressed. It seems like a really great formula for presenting interesting information with lots of engaging humor. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

This was also the first episode of You're the Expert I'd heard, and I'm very impressed. It seems like a really great formula for presenting interesting information with lots of engaging humor.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on theexpertshow.com
  • Check out more You're the Expert
  • Subscribe to You're the Expert
  • Episode originally published on August 13, 2015
Dr. Alexandra Horowitz is the head of Barnard's Canine Cognition Lab. She's also our first ever repeat guest! She was so great the first time, we had to have her on again with our new format. Panelists Mara Wilson, H. Jon Benjamin, and Josh Gondelman try to guess what Alexandra studies and then interview her about her work. Learn the truth about alpha males, guilty dog faces, and what a dog sees in the mirror.

item.title: Reconcilable Differences: 50 Shades of John
item.itunes:subtitle: Behind the Siracusa
item.itunes:author: Reconcilable Differences
item.description:
John Siracusa is most well-known on the Internet for his library of comprehensive reviews of Mac OS X on Ars Technica, his concluded tech podcast *Hypercritical*, and as one third of the ongoing *Accidental Tech Podcast*. *Hypercritical*, which concluded 2 years ago, is still my favorite podcast—not directly because of any of the topics it covered (though those were usually interesting to tech geeks), but because of the way Siracusa was able to so effectively present and construct arguments about a wide variety of topics. In *Reconcilable Differences*, he and Merlin Mann (another internet figure known in the podcasting sphere for his long-running shows *Back to Work* and *Roderick on the Line*) sit down and try to figure out how each other ticks by sharing stories and philosophies.
The thing is—two white dudes ruminating on life and sharing personal stories sounds like it could be extremely egotistical and utterly unpleasant. But that couldn't be farther from the truth with *Reconcilable Differences*. This podcast will obviously be more enjoyable if you have some familiarity with the hosts, but I think even people new to these voices will get something out of this conversation, which attempts to tackle the questions "how does John's mind work, and how did he get that way?". You'll get more out of that answer if you have a preexisting fascination with how his mind works, but I think the discussion should be interesting regardless. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on relay.fm
  • Check out more Reconcilable Differences
  • Subscribe to Reconcilable Differences
  • Episode originally published on August 13, 2015
This week, John and Merlin do some follow-up on John's picky eating and his family's failures at meal planning. Both men cop to loving soup. Then on to the big topic: how does John's mind work, and how did he get that way?

item.title: ARRVLS: Mama, I’m A Girl
item.itunes:subtitle: Mama, I'm a Girl
item.itunes:author: ARRVLS
item.description:
I've been thinking about how to feature Marlo Mack's incredible, inspiring podcast *How To Be a Girl* since I discovered it a couple weeks ago, and how to encourage people to go back and listen to the podcast's back catalogue. And then this episode of *ARRVLS*, an overview of the story behind *How To Be a Girl*, came along and answered that question. This episode is an overview of the story behind *How To Be a Girl*, and a great introduction to the podcast.
If you enjoyed this episode, be sure to listen to the entire back catalogue of *How To Be a Girl* at [howtobeagirlpodcast.com](http://www.howtobeagirlpodcast.com/). With only 8 episodes and most under 10 minutes, it's very accessible. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on arrvls.com
  • Check out more ARRVLS
  • Subscribe to ARRVLS
  • Episode originally published on August 13, 2015
“Mommy, something went wrong in your tummy. Put me back so I can come out a girl.” Marlo heard these words from her four-year-old child. Despite being born with male organs, her child has insisted she’s a girl ever since she could form complete sentences. Marlo discusses switching names and pronouns, clothes shopping, supporting her daughter’s decision on whom she does or doesn’t tell, and her own complicated and beautiful experience of having a child she once perceived as a little boy become a little girl.

item.title: Freakonomics Radio: Why Do We Follow the News?
item.itunes:subtitle: Why follow news?
item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio
item.description:
A couple months ago while listening to Hello Internet, professional YouTube explainer CGP Grey talked about his reasons for not following the news. He raised an interesting question that left a mark on me: is keeping up with the news as righteous, necessary, and morally imperative as we commonly believe?
This episode of *Freakonomics Radio* grazes that question, but mainly tackles the related question of *why* we actually follow the news, and if it is for the righteousness, necessity, and moral imperatives that we commonly assume. It's an interesting question, and this podcast does a great job exploring it from multiple perspectives while giving the listener lots to think about. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out more Freakonomics Radio
  • Subscribe to Freakonomics Radio
  • Episode originally published on August 5, 2015
There are all kinds of civics-class answers to that question. But how true are they? Could it be that we like to read about war, politics, and miscellaneous heartbreak simply because it's (gasp) entertaining?

item.title: This American Life #563: The Problem We All Live With - Part Two
item.itunes:subtitle: Forcing desegregation
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.description:
You probably may have already seen this coming, but here's the follow-up to Monday's episode. If you haven't listened to the first part of [The Problem We All Live With](http://podpodpodcast.com/featured/4-tal-the-problem-we-all-live-with/), start there first.
**Note:** *This American Life* only keeps a small number of recent episodes available in their podcast feed, which means I suspect this episode will only download normally for about 2.5 weeks after posting. If you want to listen after then, you can listen (along with the rest of their archive) on [*This American Life*'s website](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/563/the-problem-we-all-live-with-part-two).
**Similar:** *This American Life* has been hitting it out of the park covering stories about race this year. If you enjoyed this episode, you should *definitely* check out [Cops See It Differently, Part One](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/547/cops-see-it-differently-part-one) (Feb 6, 2015), [Cops See It Differently, Part Two](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/548/cops-see-it-differently-part-two) (Feb 13, 2015), and [Three Miles](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/550/three-miles) (Mar 13, 2015).
**Editorial Note:** I'm unsure how to handle two-part episodes like these going forward. What I'm doing here with devoting 2/3 of the week to one story feels unfair to people who weren't interested in the first half, but I thought this particular story was gripping enough to warrant the focus. Other alternatives I've considered: just post the first episode in the feed, and link to the following parts in the show notes (but I bet a lot of people wouldn't notice and would completely miss out on the following parts); or include both parts in the feed on a single day (but this contradicts one of my main goals, which is to make this feed light and digestible). I don't really know. Let me know what you think on [Twitter]({{ site.twitter.jeff_url }}). If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.
item.itunes:summary:
You probably may have already seen this coming, but here's the follow-up to Monday's episode. If you haven't listened to the first part of [The Problem We All Live With](http://podpodpodcast.com/featured/4-tal-the-problem-we-all-live-with/), start there first.
**Note:** *This American Life* only keeps a small number of recent episodes available in their podcast feed, which means I suspect this episode will only download normally for about 2.5 weeks after posting. If you want to listen after then, you can listen (along with the rest of their archive) on [*This American Life*'s website](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/563/the-problem-we-all-live-with-part-two).
**Similar:** *This American Life* has been hitting it out of the park covering stories about race this year. If you enjoyed this episode, you should *definitely* check out [Cops See It Differently, Part One](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/547/cops-see-it-differently-part-one) (Feb 6, 2015), [Cops See It Differently, Part Two](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/548/cops-see-it-differently-part-two) (Feb 13, 2015), and [Three Miles](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/550/three-miles) (Mar 13, 2015).
**Editorial Note:** I'm unsure how to handle two-part episodes like these going forward. What I'm doing here with devoting 2/3 of the week to one story feels unfair to people who weren't interested in the first half, but I thought this particular story was gripping enough to warrant the focus. Other alternatives I've considered: just post the first episode in the feed, and link to the following parts in the show notes (but I bet a lot of people wouldn't notice and would completely miss out on the following parts); or include both parts in the feed on a single day (but this contradicts one of my main goals, which is to make this feed light and digestible). I don't really know. Let me know what you think on [Twitter]({{ site.twitter.jeff_url }}). If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

What I'm doing here with devoting 2/3 of the week to one story feels unfair to people who weren't interested in the first half, but I thought this particular story was gripping enough to warrant the focus. Other alternatives I've considered: just post the first episode in the feed, and link to the following parts in the show notes (but I bet a lot of people wouldn't notice and would completely miss out on the following parts); or include both parts in the feed on a single day (but this contradicts one of my main goals, which is to make this feed light and digestible). I don't really know. Let me know what you think on Twitter.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on thisamericanlife.org
  • Check out more This American Life
  • Subscribe to This American Life
  • Episode originally published on August 9, 2015
Last week we looked at a school district integrating by accident. This week: a city going all out to integrate its schools. Plus, a girl who comes up with her own one-woman integration plan.

item.title: This American Life #562: The Problem We All Live With
item.itunes:subtitle: Accidental desegregation
item.itunes:author: This American Life
item.description:
*This American Life* is perhaps the biggest podcast out there, so featuring it here to some degree feels a bit odd. This episode isn't being featured to say “hey, you should check out this podcast you may not have heard of,” but rather: “this episode is extremely well-done, thought-provoking, very important, and you should definitely listen.”
**Note:** *This American Life* only keeps a small number of recent episodes available in their podcast feed, which means I suspect this episode will only download normally for about 2 weeks after posting. If you want to listen after then, you can listen (along with the rest of their archive) on [*This American Life*'s website](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/562/the-problem-we-all-live-with).
**Similar:** *This American Life* has been hitting it out of the park covering stories about race this year. If you enjoyed this episode, you should *definitely* check out [Cops See It Differently, Part One](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/547/cops-see-it-differently-part-one) (Feb 6, 2015), [Cops See It Differently, Part Two](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/548/cops-see-it-differently-part-two) (Feb 13, 2015), and [Three Miles](http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/550/three-miles) (Mar 13, 2015).
If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Check out this episode on thisamericanlife.org
  • Check out more This American Life
  • Subscribe to This American Life
  • Episode originally published on August 2, 2015
Right now, all sorts of people are trying to rethink and reinvent education, to get poor minority kids performing as well as white kids. But there's one thing nobody tries anymore, despite lots of evidence that it works: desegregation. Nikole Hannah-Jones looks at a district that, not long ago, accidentally launched a desegregation program. First of a two-part series.

item.title: Note to Self: This is Your Brain On Online Shopping
item.itunes:subtitle: UX of online shopping
item.itunes:author: Note to Self
item.description: This is a pretty great primer to the concept and practice of UX (user experience) research. It's an interesting look behind the process of UX research, but also a great introduction to how questions of UX affect software and experiences that continue to become more significant in our lives. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Episode originally published on Aug 5, 2015
Manoush visits Etsy's Usability Lab (UX) to figure out why she might buy six sweaters she never wears.

item.title: Another Round #19: Was That A Microaggression Or Just Tuesday?
item.itunes:subtitle: Microagression Tuesday
item.itunes:author: Another Round
item.description:
Come to *Another Round* to hear two smart women discuss race and social justice; stay for the squirreltalk and insightful interviews. If you're woke, listen to have fun hearing about issues you care about; if you're not woke (or don't know what that word means and think I'm using the past participle of 'wake' incorrectly), listen to have fun hearing new voices and seeing different perspectives.
With that general introduction to *Another Round* out of the way, this episode, with guest Audie Cornish from NPR's *All Things Considered*, is great for all of the reasons that *Another Round* is typically great. Some highlights: reading Martin Luther King quotes to a racist fish, the whiteness of public radio voices, and perspective on microagressions. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

  • Episode originally published on Aug 4, 2015
Tracy tells the story about her racist goldfish, and we chat with Audie Cornish, host of NPR's All Things Considered. Plus: more inspirational words from Kanye West.

item.title: 99% Invisible #173: Awareness
item.itunes:subtitle: A simple little symbol
item.itunes:author: 99% Invisible
item.description: If you don't listen to *99% Invisible* regularly, you probably should. Some episodes focus on topics that mostly appeal to design or architecture nerds, but every now and then *99% Invisible* hits it out of the park with a story that resonates with basically anyone. This episode is about a design, but really it's about the powerful social impact that a simple little design can achieve. If you have thoughts about this episode, join the discusssion on http://podpodpodcast.com.

Some episodes focus on topics that mostly appeal to design or architecture nerds, but every now and then 99% Invisible hits it out of the park with a story that resonates with basically anyone.   • Check out this episode on 99pi.org
  • Check out more 99% Invisible
  • Subscribe to 99% Invisible
  • Episode originally published on July 22, 2015
By the late 1980s, AIDS had been in the United States for almost a decade. AIDS had be the number one killer of young men in New York City, then of young men in the country, then of young men and women in the country. Despite the gravity of the AIDS crisis, in the late 1980s there was little public acknowledgement of AIDS. A group of artists in Manhattan decided to change that. New York artist Patrick O’Connel would spend days visiting friends in the hospital, going to funerals, and coming home to a panicked answering machine message from friends who just learned they were sick. O’Connel and other artists banded together and started making art in response to AIDS. In 1988 they began calling their collective Visual AIDS. Visual AIDS held public events and organized gallery shows to raise AIDS awareness. But of all the work the group did, they made their biggest impact with a simple little symbol. A little concept that, at the time, was very novel: The AIDS awareness ribbon.
